comment: I remember trying this and not being impressed, and I can't remember all the reasons and that's not fair, I know. I just think it was kind of harsh and astringent, beyond the big big smoke.
Didn't like it at first, but warmed up to it after a few months.  Certainly not for mixing.  Seems more like a winter whiskey.

I was lucky enough to find a glass of this at a winery bistro outside of Lexington. Very cool! It is super smoky, obviously, but a little more complex than just that.  Very savory, highly recommended.
Warm and sweet with lingering smokiness
Tasty flavored not overpowering alcohol.  Close your eyes and you'll see yourself outdoors won a nice fire going enjoying the evening glow.  Or you'll be sure to bring it along camping.

Nose : sweet spicy smoke (reminds me of anejo Tequila) Sip: sweet, chocolate Finish: campfire, and liquorice.   This tast like a smokey Stranahans to me and smells like Tequila.  I am definitely not schooled in single malts or Scotch so I have a hard time placing these flavors. Not a bad drink but can't say I would make this a daily affair. If you want something different from the norm give this a try you won't be sorry. (sample provided by a friend, Thanks Casey)
I'm probably just not ready for maverick style whiskey.  Too many flavors happening at the same time, just couldn't figure out any one certain stand out taste on the palette
Very unique and distinctive nose. Tries to mimic the smoke of an Islay whiskey but fails to do so unfortunately.
A smokey beginning when you open the bottle but it is smooth to the taste. A great combination that finishes like a single malt
One of the best whiskeys I've had. Has a taste of single malt smokey Ness and sweetness
Smoother than you would think for something called triple smoke.  Spicier linger than the flavor profile lets on.  Best straight.
This definitely reminds you of an Islay Scotch with bourbon roots. You have taste of vanilla and tobacco with some peat. I enjoyed it.

Maraschino and peach nose, and the flavor adds no surprises. Peach pie, marzipan, plum, toasted marshmallow,hint of cinnamon or clove. Nice linger. Smoke comes out the longer you drink it, but pretty lacking at first. Cherry hookah in a bottle.
Smokey, without the obnoxious bacon flavor that most Scotches develop after a few sips. A winner.

Took a tour of the distillery today. This is a killer whiskey....well balanced...still tastes a little young to me. I'd like to taste it barreled for a few more years but it's still delicious . The nose is sweet, peach, raisin, banana and plum. The palette is smokey with a distant peat, marshmallow, chocolate, clove and cherry. It finishes warm, smooth, and smokey with a touch of licorice and vanilla. 
  Imagine a sweet Kentucky bourbon had a baby with an islay Scotch!
Closer to a 4.25.  With a bit higher proof, true greatness would have been achieved. As it stands, it's an excellent whiskey with a compelling flavor profile. Check it out!

Despite being called Triple Smoke, the smokiness in this is expertly nuanced with a subtle fruitiness. Honestly something about this is reminds me very strongly of Rice Krispy Treats with chocolate chips.
Similar to a very peated Scotch, without the smoothness nor nice finish.  Not bad, overall, though.  I'd rather have an average Scotch.
Loved the idea, but felt like it didn't quite pull it off.  That said, would have it again.
Smokey and sweet on the nose.   Very smooth.  If you like islay scotch and bourbon I recommend giving this a try.

The smoke is mild, especially on the nose, when compared to some of the peatier scotches, but it develops nicely through the palate and finish. Very smooth with no booze burn at all. Traces of both cherrywood and peat smoke come alongside a woody sweetness and a hint of salt.
Smokey up front but smooth fruit finish
You can smell the cask.  The smoke and oak off of this is silly.  So smooth.  My face is numb
Smiley and sweeet.  Nice for sipping.
Sweet, smokey, and playful. I only wish they bottled it at least at 43%.
10/20/16 corsair distillery in Wedgewood w/Paul Finelli

A novel approach to smoky single malt. The nose is a bit of campfire, caramel, and black pepper. The palate explodes with a burst of smoke and black pepper, then mellows into a buttery, lingering, sweet vanilla and caramel. Subtle it isn't, but that doesn't have to be a bad thing.
Tasted at Whiskey Obsession 2018. Wuldfire is much better
Stunning smoky as all get out. Yummy.
would give 3.5 if I could--balanced and rich, nothing exceptional, but well done.

This one is really interesting, in a good way...

I have a "ritual" for every new whiskey (or whisky) I try... Always in a glencairn glass, first neat, then with a little (2 - 6)drops of water, then with an ice cube. This whiskey is a perfect example of how much things can change with small additions to whiskey

Neat - nose =very sweet with the grains taking center stage (almost like cheerios) palate = more of the same, sweet, with the malt really coming through, quite tasty finish = finally getting the smoke I was expecting, but definitely still sweet (guessing that's the hickory)

With 6 drops of water - pretty much the same, but the smoke starts coming through a little more on the palate, but still not on the nose

Single ice cube - wow, huge difference, the smoke(s) really take center stage but without taking away from the grainy malty flavors, just adding to and accenting them

This is easily one of my favorite new drams, not quite a 5,but easily a 4.5 can't wait to visit them for a tour this autumn since my (non whiskey drinking) wife had a thing for distillery tours after our recent visit to Kentucky
Smokey BBQ! Notes of leather smoked meat in the nose. Dark caramel with intense smoke. Very BBQ PIT
Saw this in whisky advocate us distillery smoked with cherrywood, beechwood,and peat $45 40% abv
No smoke. Young-tasting whiskey. Aged in small barrels, easily identifiable.
Amazing flavor. An American whiskey made in a traditional Irish style. A typical Irish flavor but with a bold smoke on the back end. A truly unique flavor that must be tried to truly understand.

While this seems like a gimmick at first glance, this whiskey is definitely in a league of its own. Smokey on the nose, as one would expect, that pairs with a light rubbery note that continues throughout and to the finish. Hints of cherry and apple on the palate as well make this one of my three missing links between Scotch and Whiskey. Well worth the money
Mesquite smoke, light peat, red apple. Not very smokey but maybe my palette was messed up.

Birthday review!  It has a very awesome nose.  Cherries, both black and regular.  Sweet corn, smoke, peat, and vanilla.  Medium mouth coat of a nice spice, hint of black pepper, smoky, vanilla, and toffee on the palate.  It’s like a scotch, bourbon, and rye in one sitting, thankfully without the dill.  Solid performance if you like a sweet buttery long finish too.  4.0. Age could make this more complex, but why bitch.
It is what they say it is.   Heavy smoke, not sure about getting another.
This is solid. Love the smoke taste. Sampled a bunch when I was in Nashville. Will be buying more bottles.
Good and different. A little too sweet for me. Would make a good, different bottle to take to a party.

For the price, this is worth every cent. The peat-smoked barley coats the inside of your mouth, giving a tight mouthfeel. The cherry wood is very pronounced in this bottle, overpowering the beechwood in most sips. You'll want to be in the mood for a good cherry taste before sipping this... However, the flavors of honey, malted barley, and caramel make this still very much enjoyable on any given day.

The visitor center is burning down, and you're trying to avoid smoke inhalation. Luckily the velociraptors will be struggling with breathing too. Get out of there while they're distracted.

A hefty amount of smoke, throughout the palate. Fortunately it never feels like an overload. It doesn't stay with you for very long, but make sure you give yourself time if you're trying another new whiskey afterwards.
Matt and Heidi’s from Nashville, TN. Sampled some before going to dinner. Matt had recently traveled to Nashville.
Cherry forward on the nose and palatte.  Sweetness from fruits.  Smoke builds on the mouth and in the long finish.  A great daily drinker especially for a Manhattan lover.
Smoked caramel, chocolate, a bit of heat, smooth finish

American single malts should be far more common than they are. I think we could easily surpass the UK with some effort. The Reservoir Dogs packaging is cheesy but I really enjoyed this one. It's like the Stooges or Hanoi Rocks of whisky. Awesome, unique, bold, punk, and not afraid to flaunt it. As an ex-smoker I really enjoyed the smoke.

Quite unique.  The cherry wood gives it a strong sweet and rounded taste.   The smoke is present, but far less prominent than I expected given the name.  But it's a pleasant smoke, particularly on the finish.  This is probably a young whiskey, but the three barrels round it out so nicely that it has an older demeanor.  I tried this on two consecutive nights, and liked it better on night 2.   I think it's unique enough that i needed a second glance.

Nose:  gun oil, sweet, cherry, berries, a little bit of smoke
Palate:  sweet, very smokey, banana taffy, a little bit of malt, floral, a little spicy
Finish:  moderately spicy, smokey (peat and other), gun oil again.

This is a very unique whiskey.  It is complex and interesting, but not very enjoyable.  It is a little like drinking the smells that come to mind when cleaning a gun.  I really like the idea behind it and love that whiskey makers are experimenting and getting creative.  Unfortunately this one is just not my taste.
Smokey nose, Smokey and a little sweet up front and on the finish. A little bit pipe smoke. Ok, but not my favorite.
Incredible triad of flavors. Bright and fruity on the tongue, bourbon texture and heavy peat linger. Fantastic
Sweet smoke. Spice. Vanilla. Cherry notes.
Disappointed in this one. It’s difficult to verbalize: the flavor profile is fine, but it’s thin in a way that makes it taste watered down. I don’t think I’ll replace this bottle.

It's literally the best parts of every whiskey thrown together. You've got the sweet cherry notes of a bourbon. The spice of a rye. The peaty smoke of a Scotch. A little bit of vanilla cookie of the Irish. I can literally not rave enough about the whiskey. So much so that I decided to make it my first pour on my birthday! Great smoky cherry notes on the nose and an even greater fruity taste that lingers into a smoke-filled finish. God bless Corsair Distillery

Nose: Oak, apple, cherry, peaches, nectarines, lemongrass, vanilla,
Taste: malt, baking spice, apples, light smoke. chocolate, pears

This is interesting in that it is a good whiskey, but the smoke barely presents itself. Its actually a lot fruitier and herbal.

After doing a bourbon tasting, the smoke has become more clear in this than ever before. You can really smell the peat and BBQ smoke that Corsair advertises in the Triple Smoke name, but comparing it to an Ardbeg really brings out the sweetness. The taste still has that beautiful cherry and orange note with that beautiful peat that reminds me of the great Scottish isles

Well, ladies and gentlemen, I've found my favorite whiskey. An awesome medicinal cherry (Think Luden's cough drops) on the nose with some beautiful smoke flowing around it welcomes you to the Triple Smoke experience. Corsair has become a constant stop for me whenever I visit Nashville, exclusively because of this whiskey. Even those who stray away from smoke should try this whiskey because all that smoke is offset by these beautiful fruity notes that result in an amazingly sweet whiskey with an awesome peaty finish. I tried it with a bit of water tonight and it opened up so much more, providing more of that smoke and fruit and almost a bit of BBQ sauce.
Great smokey aroma. Smoke and dark cherry. Rich and really smooth. Faint peat flavor.

The nose is like enjoying a cherry-orange popsicle by a bonfire. Beautiful sweet notes with a punch of smoke behind it. The taste starts with those lovely sweet notes that finishes into a pure Islay scotch experience thanks to the peat
